com.gf
Class Filter

java.lang.Object
  com.gf.InvocationObject
      com.gf.Filter
Direct Known Subclasses:
ConnectionInInvoke, InvocationReaderFilter, UserTransactionInInvoke
public abstract class Filter
extends InvocationObject

Use Filter for handle every Action before Interceptors and targeted Handler.

Note:

  • Filter handle every Action unlike Interceptor or Handler.
  • If there are few filters use @Order annotaion for to determine the filters order.

The order of processing:

  • Filters
  • Interceptors
  • Handler

Interceptors and Handlers can call subInvoke method.
In this case the order of processing:

  • Filters (was called only once)
  • Interceptors
    • Sub Interceptors
    • Sub Handler
  • Handler
    • Sub Interceptors
    • Sub Handler

Example: 

 //filter
 public class SomeFilter extends Filter {
 
   public void invoke(Action<?, ?> action, FilterChain chain) throws Exception {
     
     Date begin = new Date();
     log.info("begin: "+begin);
     
     try {
       //next handler
       chain.doNext();
     }finally {
       long worktime = System.currentTimeMillis() - begin.getTime();
       log.info("worktime: "+worktime+"ms");
     }
   }
 }
 
 //handler
 @Mapping(SomeAction.class)
 public class SomeHandler extends Handler<SomeAction>{
 
   public void invoke(SomeAction action) throws Exception {
     String input = action.input();
     action.setOutput(input);
   }
 }
 
 //engine
 Engine engine = new Engine();
 engine.putHandler(SomeHandler.class);
 engine.putFilter(SomeFilter.class);
 engine.invoke(new SomeAction());

Author:
Evgeny Dolganov
See Also:
Order, Action, Handler, Interceptor, Engine

Method Detail

invoke

public abstract void invoke(Action<?,?> action,
                            FilterChain chain)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
Process the action.

Parameters:
chain - interface to call next filter, interceptor or handler
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

addToInvocationContext

protected void addToInvocationContext(java.lang.Object ob)
Add some object to current invocation context. So this object can be injected into next filters, interceptors, handlers.

Example: 

 //filter
 public class SomeFilter extends Filter {
   
   @Override
   public void invoke(Action<?, ?> action, FilterChain chain) throws Exception {
     
     Connection connection = getConnection();
     addToInvocationContext(connection);
     
     try {
       chain.doNext();
     }finally {
       connection.close();
     }
     
   }
 
 }
 
 @Mapping(SomeAction.class)
 public class SomeHandler extends Handler<SomeAction>{
   
   @Inject
   Connection connection; //<------------ object from filter
 
   @Override
   public void invoke(SomeAction action) throws Exception {
     
     Statement statement = connection.createStatement();
     ResultSet rs = statement.executeQuery("select count(*) from Users");
     rs.next();
     long count = rs.getLong(1);
     action.setOutput(count);
     rs.close();
     
   }
 
 }

setInvocationContext

public void setInvocationContext(InvocationContextService invocationContext)
